revision.text:
{{other people}} {{pp-pc1}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Bill Murray | image = Bill Murray by Gage Skidmore.jpg | caption = Murray at the 2015 [[San Diego Comic-Con]] | birth_name = William James Murray | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1950|9|21}} | birth_place = [[Evanston, Illinois]], U.S.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110408155814/http://cookcountyclerk.com/sweethomecookcounty/Pages/BillMurray.aspx Bill Murray]. Cookcountyclerk.com | years_active = 1973–present | occupation = {{flatlist| * Actor * comedian * writer }} | spouse = {{marriage|Margaret Kelly
|1981|1996|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Jennifer Butler
|1997|2008|reason=divorced}} | children = 6 | family = [[John Murray (actor)|John Murray]] (brother)
[[Joel Murray]] (brother)
[[Brian Doyle-Murray]] (brother) }} '''William James Murray''' (born September 21, 1950) is an American actor, comedian, and writer. He first gained exposure on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', a series of performances that earned him his first [[Emmy Award]], and later starred in comedy films—including ''[[Meatballs (film)|Meatballs]]'' (1979), ''[[Caddyshack]]'' (1980), ''[[Stripes (film)|Stripes]]'' (1981), ''[[Tootsie]]'' (1982), ''[[Ghostbusters]]'' (1984), ''[[Scrooged]]'' (1988), ''[[Ghostbusters II]]'' (1989), ''[[What About Bob?]]'' (1991), and ''[[Groundhog Day (film)|Groundhog Day]]'' (1993). He also co-directed ''[[Quick Change]]'' (1990). Murray garnered additional critical acclaim later in his career, starring in ''[[Lost in Translation (film)|Lost in Translation]]'' (2003), which earned him a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor - Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Golden Globe]] and a [[BAFTA Award for Best Actor]], as well as an [[Academy Award]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]], and for frequently collaborating with director [[Wes Anderson]]. He also received Golden Globe nominations for his roles in ''Ghostbusters'', ''[[Rushmore (film)|Rushmore]]'' (1998), ''[[Hyde Park on Hudson]]'' (2012), ''[[St. Vincent (film)|St. Vincent]]'' (2014), and the [[HBO]] miniseries [[Olive Kitteridge (miniseries)|''Olive Kitteridge'']] (2014), for which he later won his second [[Primetime Emmy]] Award. Murray received the [[Mark Twain Prize for American Humor]] in 2016.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/bill-murray-accepts-his-mark-twain-prize-i-dreaded-this/2016/10/23/1458ce0e-9962-11e6-9980-50913d68eacb_story.html |title=Bill Murray accepts Mark Twain Prize: ‘As much as I dreaded this ... there’s love’ |last1=McGlone |first1=Peggy |last2= |first2= |date=October 23, 2016 |website= |publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' |access-date=November 3, 2016 |quote=}} His comedy is known for its [[deadpan]] delivery.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/what-to-watch/bill-murray-best-worst-movies/|title=Will Bill Murray ever make another good movie?|last=Bernstein|first=Jonathan|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=October 30, 2015|accessdate=November 3, 2015}} ==Early life== Murray was born on September 21, 1950, in [[Evanston, Illinois]], to Lucille (née Collins), a mail-room clerk, and Edward Joseph Murray II, a lumber salesman. He was raised in [[Wilmette, Illinois]], a northern suburb of Chicago.{{cite news|title=Bill Murray profile|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/24/Bill-Murray.html|publisher=Film Reference|accessdate=November 12, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071227054158/http://www.filmreference.com/film/24/Bill-Murray.html|archivedate=December 27, 2007|deadurl=no}}{{cite news|title=Bill Murray Family Tree|url=http://landing.ancestry.com/famoustree/Tree.aspx?name=murray&sourceCode=6865|publisher=[[Ancestry.com]]|accessdate=November 12, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071227060310/http://landing.ancestry.com/famoustree/Tree.aspx?name=murray&sourceCode=6865|archivedate=December 27, 2007|deadurl=yes}} Murray and his eight siblings were raised in a [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] [[Irish Americans|Irish-American]] family.{{cite news|last=Elder |first=Sean |url=http://www.salon.com/people/bc/2001/02/06/murray/index.html |title=Brilliant Careers: Bill Murray |work=Salon.com |accessdate=November 12, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011090533/http://salon.com/people/bc/2001/02/06/murray/index.html |archivedate=October 11, 2008 |df= }} Three of his siblings, [[John Murray (actor)|John Murray]], [[Joel Murray]], and [[Brian Doyle-Murray]], are also actors. A sister, Nancy, is an [[Adrian Dominican Sisters|Adrian Dominican]] nun in [[Michigan]], who has traveled the United States in a one-woman program, portraying [[Catherine of Siena|St. Catherine of Siena]].[http://www.macombdaily.com/articles/2010/05/13/entertainment/srv0000008258835.txt "Bill Murray's Sister to Portray Saint at Local Churches"] {{dead link|date=May 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, ''The Macomb Daily'', May 13, 2010; retrieved on June 26, 2010. Their father died in 1967 at the age of 46 from complications of [[diabetes]] when Bill was 17 years old.{{cite news|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/11/20/magazine/the-rumpled-anarchy-of-bill-murray.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|title=The Rumpled Anarchy of Bill Murray|first=Timothy|last=White|date=November 20, 1988|accessdate=June 6, 2013}}[https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800022908/bio Bill Murray profile] at Yahoo! Movies {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114053816/http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800022908/bio |date=January 14, 2012 }} As a youth, Murray read children's biographies of American heroes like [[Kit Carson]], [[Wild Bill Hickok]], and [[Davy Crockett]]. He attended St. Joseph's grade school and [[Loyola Academy]]. During his teen years, he worked as a [[golf caddy]] to fund his education at the Jesuit high school.{{cite book|last1=Murray|first1=Bill|last2=Peper|first2=George|title=Cinderella Story: My Life in Golf|year=1999|publisher=[[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]]|isbn=0-385-49571-4}} One of his sisters had [[polio]] and his mother suffered several miscarriages. During his teen years he was the lead singer of a rock band called the Dutch Masters and took part in high school and community theater.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} After graduating, Murray attended [[Regis University]] in [[Denver]], Colorado, taking pre-medical courses. He quickly dropped out, returning to Illinois. Decades later, in 2007, Regis awarded him an [[honorary degree|honorary]] Doctor of Humanities degree.{{cite news| url= http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_6391555| title= Regis University dropout Bill Murray earns stripes with honorary degree|work= [[The Denver Post]]| date= July 17, 2007| accessdate= March 9, 2010}} On September 21, 1970, his 20th birthday, the police arrested Murray at Chicago's [[O'Hare Airport]] for trying to smuggle {{convert|10|lbs|kg|abbr=on}} of [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]], which he had allegedly intended to sell. The drugs were discovered when Murray joked to the passenger next to him that he was smuggling. Murray was convicted and sentenced to [[probation]]. ==Career== ===Second City=== With an invitation from his older brother, [[Brian Doyle-Murray|Brian]], Murray got his start at [[The Second City]] in Chicago, an [[improvisational comedy]] troupe, studying under [[Del Close]].{{cite news|last=Chase|first=Chris|title=Bill Murray, A Black Sheep Now in ''Stripes''|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 3, 1981}} In 1974, he moved to New York City and was recruited by [[John Belushi]]{{cite news |last=Carr |first=Jay |title=Bill Murray's Somber Side |work=[[Boston Globe]] |date=November 20, 1988}} as a featured player on ''[[The National Lampoon Radio Hour]]''. ===''Saturday Night Live''=== In 1975, an [[Off-Broadway]] version of a ''Lampoon'' show led to his first television role as a cast member of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] variety show ''[[Saturday Night Live with Howard Cosell]]''. That same season, another variety show titled ''[[Saturday Night Live|NBC's Saturday Night]]'' premiered. Cosell's show lasted just one season, canceled in early 1976. After working in Los Angeles with the "guerrilla video" commune [[TVTV (video collective)|TVTV]] on several projects, Murray rose to prominence in 1976. He officially joined the cast of [[NBC]]'s ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' for the show's second season, following the departure of [[Chevy Chase]].{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/cultural-comment/nine-lives-saturday-night-live|title=The Nine Lives of "Saturday Night Live"|last=Crouch|first=Ian|date=October 21, 2014|publisher=[[The New Yorker]]|accessdate=December 25, 2014}} Murray was with ''SNL'' for three seasons from 1977 to 1980.{{IMDb name| id= 0000195 |name= Bill Murray}} A ''[[Rutland Weekend Television]]'' sketch [[Eric Idle]] brought for his appearance on ''SNL'' developed into the 1978 [[mockumentary]] ''[[All You Need Is Cash]]'' with Murray (alongside other ''SNL'' cast members) appearing as "Bill Murray the K", a send-up of New York radio host [[Murray the K]], in a segment of the film that is a parody of the [[Albert and David Maysles|Maysles Brothers]]'s documentary ''[[The Beatles: The First U.S. Visit]]''. During the first few seasons of ''SNL'', Murray engaged in a romantic relationship with fellow cast member [[Gilda Radner]].{{cite book| last=Radner |first=Gilda |authorlink= Gilda Radner | title= It's Always Something |location= New York |publisher= Simon & Schuster |year= 1989}} ===Film career=== [[File:BillMurraySept10TIFF.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Murray at the [[2010 Toronto International Film Festival]]]] Murray landed his first starring role with the film ''[[Meatballs (film)|Meatballs]]'' in 1979. He followed this up with his portrayal of [[Hunter S. Thompson]] in 1980's ''[[Where the Buffalo Roam]]''. In the early 1980s, he starred in a string of box-office hits, including ''[[Caddyshack]]'', ''[[Stripes (film)|Stripes]]'', and ''[[Tootsie]]''. Murray was the first guest on NBC's ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'' on February 1, 1982. He later appeared on the first episode of the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' on August 30, 1993, when the show moved to CBS. On January 31, 2012 – 30 years after his first appearance with Letterman – Murray appeared again on his talk show. He appeared as Letterman's final guest when the host retired on May 20, 2015.{{cite news|first=James|last=Hibberd |url=http://time.com/3860153/david-letterman-bill-murray/ |title= David Letterman’s Final Guest Is Bill Murray| work=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]] |date= May 15, 2015|accessdate=May 17, 2015}} Murray began work on a [[The Razor's Edge (1984 film)|film adaptation]] of the novel ''[[The Razor's Edge]]''. The film, which Murray co-wrote, was his first starring role in a [[dramatic film]]. He later agreed with [[Columbia Pictures]] to star in ''[[Ghostbusters]]''—in a role originally written for [[John Belushi]]—to get financing for ''The Razor's Edge''.{{cite web|first= Dan |last= Fierman |url= https://www.gq.com/entertainment/celebrities/201008/bill-murray-dan-fierman-gq-interview |title= Bill Murray Is Ready To See You Now| work=[[GQ]] |date= August 2010|accessdate=July 29, 2012}} ''Ghostbusters'' became the highest-grossing film of 1984 and the highest-grossing comedy of all-time.{{cite news|title='Ghostbusters' Tops Comedies|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=January 16, 1985|page=16}} ''The Razor's Edge'', which was filmed before ''Ghostbusters'' but not released until after, was a box-office flop. Upset over the failure of ''The Razor's Edge'', Murray took four years off from acting to study philosophy and history at the [[University of Paris|Sorbonne]], frequent the [[Cinémathèque Française|Cinémathèque]] in Paris, and spend time with his family in their [[Hudson River Valley]] home. During that time, his second son, Luke, was born. With the exception of a [[cameo appearance]] in the 1986 movie ''[[Little Shop of Horrors (film)|Little Shop of Horrors]]'', he did not make any appearances in films, though he did participate in several public readings in [[Manhattan]] organized by playwright/director Timothy Mayer and in a stage production of [[Bertolt Brecht]]'s ''[[Man Equals Man|A Man's a Man]]''. Murray returned to films with ''[[Scrooged]]'' in 1988 and ''[[Ghostbusters II]]'' in 1989. In 1990, Murray made his first and only attempt at directing when he co-directed ''[[Quick Change]]'' with producer [[Howard Franklin]]. His subsequent films ''[[What About Bob?]]'' (1991) and ''[[Groundhog Day (film)|Groundhog Day]]'' (1993) were box-office hits. After ''[[Groundhog Day (film)|Groundhog Day]]'', he appeared in a series of well-received supporting roles in films like ''[[Ed Wood (film)|Ed Wood]]'', ''[[Kingpin (1996 film)|Kingpin]]'', and ''[[Space Jam]]'' (where he appeared as himself). However, his starring roles in ''[[Larger than Life (film)|Larger than Life]]'' and ''[[The Man Who Knew Too Little]]'' were not as successful with critics or audiences. In 1998, he received much critical acclaim for [[Wes Anderson]]'s ''[[Rushmore (film)|Rushmore]]'', for which he won Best Supporting Actor awards from the [[New York Film Critics Circle]], the [[National Society of Film Critics]], and the [[Los Angeles Film Critics Association]] (tying with [[Billy Bob Thornton]]). Murray decided to take a turn towards more dramatic roles and experienced a resurgence in his career, taking on roles in ''[[Wild Things (film)|Wild Things]]'', ''[[Cradle Will Rock]]'', ''[[Hamlet (2000 movie)|Hamlet]]'' (as [[Polonius]]), and ''[[The Royal Tenenbaums]]''. In 2003, he appeared in [[Sofia Coppola]]'s ''[[Lost in Translation (film)|Lost in Translation]]'' and went on to earn a [[Golden Globe Award]], a [[BAFTA Award]], and an [[Independent Spirit Award]], as well as Best Actor awards from several film critic organizations.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/awards/2003/awardsandnominations.shtml |title=2003 Film Awards & Nominations |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=November 10, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080502193917/http://www.metacritic.com/film/awards/2003/awardsandnominations.shtml |archivedate=May 2, 2008 |deadurl=yes }} He was considered a favorite to win the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]], but [[Sean Penn]] ultimately won the award for his performance in ''[[Mystic River (film)|Mystic River]]''. In an interview included on the ''Lost in Translation'' DVD, Murray states that it is his favorite movie in which he has appeared. Also in 2003, he appeared in a short cameo for [[Jim Jarmusch]]'s ''[[Coffee and Cigarettes]]'', in which he played himself "hiding out" in a local coffee shop. [[File:Bill Murray, Monuments Men premiere.jpg|thumb|upright|Murray in 2014]] During this time Murray still appeared in comedic roles such as ''[[Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle|Charlie's Angels]]'' and ''[[Osmosis Jones]]''. In 2004, he provided the voice of [[Garfield]] in ''[[Garfield: The Movie]]'', and again in 2006 for ''[[Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties]]''. Murray later said that he only took the role because he was under the mistaken impression the screenplay, co-written by [[Joel Cohen (writer)|Joel Cohen]], was the work of [[Coen Brothers|Joel Coen]].{{cite news | title = Bill Murray Is Ready To See You Now | date = August 2010 | url = https://www.gq.com/entertainment/celebrities/201008/bill-murray-dan-fierman-gq-interview?printable=true | work = GQ | accessdate = March 9, 2011}} In 2004, he made his third collaboration with Wes Anderson in ''[[The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou]]'' and in 2005 his second collaboration with [[Jim Jarmusch]] in ''[[Broken Flowers]]''. That same year, Murray announced that he was taking a break from acting{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000195/bio| title= Bill Murray biography page |publisher= Internet Movie Database|accessdate=January 11, 2008}} as he had not had the time to relax since his new breakthrough in the late 1990s. He did return to the big screen for brief cameos in Wes Anderson's ''[[The Darjeeling Limited]]'' and in ''[[Get Smart (film)|Get Smart]]'' as Agent 13, the agent in the tree. In 2008, he played an important role in the [[post-apocalyptic]] film ''[[City of Ember]]'', and in 2009, played himself in a [[cameo appearance|cameo]] role in the [[zombie comedy]] ''[[Zombieland]]''. Murray provided the voice for the character Mr. Badger in the 2009 animated film ''[[Fantastic Mr. Fox (film)|Fantastic Mr. Fox]]''. [[File:Isle of Dogs - Press Conference.jpg|thumb|Murray, [[Greta Gerwig]], and [[Bryan Cranston]] at the ''Isle of Dogs'' press conference at Berlinale 2018|left]] Since 2010, Murray has been part of ensembles which received several award nominations in two Wes Anderson movies: ''[[Moonrise Kingdom]]'' (2012) and ''[[Grand Budapest Hotel]]'' (2014). Murray was nominated for a Golden Globe for his performance in the 2014 film ''[[St. Vincent (film)|St. Vincent]]''. He played a music manager in 2015’s ''[[Rock the Kasbah (film)|Rock the Kasbah]]''. In 2016, he was the voice of [[Baloo]] in Disney's live action remake of ''[[The Jungle Book (2016 film)|The Jungle Book]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Bill-Murray-Sing-Jungle-Book-Best-Song-68764.html|title=Bill Murray Will Sing The Jungle Book's Best Song |date=December 19, 2014|work=cinemablend.com}} The film earned a 95% approval rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]],{{cite web | url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_jungle_book_2016/ | title=The Jungle Book (2016) | website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | accessdate=December 19, 2017}} and Murray was nominated to for Favorite Animated Movie Voice at the People’s Choice Awards; he lost to [[Ellen DeGeneres]]. Murray appeared as Martin Heiss, a skeptical ghost debunker, in the [[reboot (fiction)|reboot]] of ''[[Ghostbusters (2016 film)|Ghostbusters]]'', which was released on July 15, 2016.{{cite web | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2015/08/09/bill-murray-new-ghostbusters-movie/31378093/ | title=Bill Murray to appear in new 'Ghostbusters' | work=USA Today | date=August 9, 2015 | accessdate=August 9, 2015 | author=Truitt, Brian}} There had been speculation that he might return to the [[Ghostbusters (franchise)|''Ghostbusters'' franchise]]{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/38625/round-and-round-we-go-more-from-bill-murray-ghostbusters-3|title=Round and Round We Go – More From Bill Murray on Ghostbusters 3}} for a rumored ''[[Ghostbusters 3]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/20949|title=Fans Convince Murray to Do Third 'Ghostbusters'?}} but he dispelled such rumors in an interview with ''[[GQ]]''. In March 2010, Murray appeared on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' and talked about his return to ''Ghostbusters III'', stating "I'd do it only if my character was killed off in the first reel."{{cite web |url=http://www.shocktillyoudrop.com/news/topnews.php?id=14322 |title=Bill Murray Talks Ghostbusters 3 on Letterman |work=ShockTilYouDrop |publisher=CraveOnline |date=March 1, 2010 |accessdate=March 22, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100406154834/http://www.shocktillyoudrop.com/news/topnews.php?id=14322 |archivedate=April 6, 2010 |deadurl=yes }} In an interview with ''GQ'', Murray said: "You know, maybe I should just do it. Maybe it'd be fun to do." In the interview, when asked "Is the third ''Ghostbusters'' movie happening? What's the story with that?", Murray replied, "It's all a bunch of crock." He was part of the ensemble cast of the 2018 animated film ''[[Isle of Dogs (film)|Isle of Dogs]]'', by [[Wes Anderson]], which premiered at the [[68th Berlin International Film Festival]]. ==Outside show business== Murray is a partner with his brothers in Murray Bros. Caddy Shack, a restaurant located near [[St. Augustine, Florida]]. He resides in [[Charleston, South Carolina]], where he is a very active community member.{{cite web |url=http://www.murraybroscaddyshack.com/ |title=Murray Bros. Caddyshack Restaurant |publisher=Murraybroscaddyshack.com |date=February 15, 2010 |accessdate=March 9, 2010 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20100304225515/http://www.murraybroscaddyshack.com/ |archivedate=March 4, 2010 |deadurl=yes }} In 1978, Murray appeared in two at-bats{{clarify|date=September 2017}} for the [[Grays Harbor Loggers]] [[Minor League Baseball]] team, credited with one hit and a lifetime batting average of .500.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com/mlb/just-a-bit-outside/story/bill-murray-snl-40th-anniversary-grays-harbor-loggers-1978-021515|title=Bill Murray's Baseball Summer: An Oral History |publisher=FoxSports.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/register/player.cgi?id=murray004wil |title=Murray's Baseball Reference page |publisher=Baseball Reference }} He is a part-owner of the [[St. Paul Saints]] independent baseball team and occasionally travels to [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]] to watch the team's games.{{cite web|url=http://saintsbaseball.com/about/ownership/ |title=St. Paul Saints ownership |publisher=Saintsbaseball.com |date= |accessdate=July 29, 2012}} He also owns part of the [[Charleston RiverDogs]],{{cite news|last=Chandler |first=Rick |url=http://offthebench.nbcsports.com/2012/06/22/yep-heres-bill-murray-and-the-miller-high-life-guy-at-a-home-run-derby-on-an-aircraft-carrier/ |title=Yep, here's Bill Murray and the Miller High Life guy at a home run derby on an aircraft carrier |date=June 22, 2012 |work=Off the Bench |publisher=NBCSports.com |accessdate=December 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120823145329/http://offthebench.nbcsports.com/2012/06/22/yep-heres-bill-murray-and-the-miller-high-life-guy-at-a-home-run-derby-on-an-aircraft-carrier/ |archivedate=August 23, 2012 |df= }} the [[Hudson Valley Renegades]],{{cite news|last=Hill|first= Lauren|url=http://www.styleweekly.com/richmond/bill-murray-partied-here/Content?oid=1368793|title=Bill Murray Partied Here| date= June 3, 2009| publisher= styleweekly.com|accessdate=December 7, 2012}} and the [[Brockton Rox]].{{cite news| last= Levensen|first=Michael|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/1151694491.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+26%2C+2006&author=Michael+Levenson&pub=Boston+Globe&desc=A+whiff+of+scandal+bruises+Brockton%2C+team%3B+Rox+official+accused+of+misusing+funds&pqatl=google|title=A whiff of scandal bruises Brockton, team; Rox official accused of misusing funds|date=October 26, 2006|publisher=''Boston Globe''|accessdate=December 7, 2012}} He has invested in a number of other minor league teams in the past, including the [[Utica Blue Sox]],{{cite news|last=Kravitz|first=Bob|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xdMbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UmIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6787,5072250&dq=utica+blue+sox+bill+murray&hl=en|title=Yes, Utica. It's Not The Big Apple, But Brett Doesn't Take Managing Lightly|date=August 11, 1985|work= [[Pittsburgh Press]] |accessdate=December 7, 2012}} the Fort Myers Miracle, the [[Salt Lake Sting]] ([[American Professional Soccer League|APSL]]), the [[Catskill Cougars]],{{cite news| last= Waddell|first= Ted|url=http://www.sc-democrat.com/archives/2000/sports/09September/05/cougars.htm|title= What's Next for Cougars?|date= September 5, 2000| publisher= Sullivan County Democrat|accessdate=July 16, 2013}} and the [[Salt Lake City Trappers]].{{cite news| last= Benson |first= Lee|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/98157/STUNG-ONCE-BY-PRO-SOCCER-SL-TRIES-AGAIN.html?pg=all|title=Stung Once By Pro Soccer, S.L. Tries Again |date= April 21, 1990| publisher= DeseretNews.com|accessdate=December 7, 2012}} In 2012 he was inducted into the [[South Atlantic League Hall of Fame]] for his ownership and investment activities in the [[South Atlantic League|league]].{{cite web|last1=Haglund|first1=David|title=Bill Murray Inducted into South Atlantic League Hall of Fame|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2012/06/20/bill_murray_south_atlantic_league_hall_of_fame_induction_speech_watch_video_.html|website=Slate.com|accessdate=April 14, 2017}} Being very detached from the Hollywood scene, Murray does not have an agent or manager and reportedly only fields offers for scripts and roles using a personal telephone number with a voice mailbox that he checks infrequently.{{cite web|url=http://rodcorp.typepad.com/rodcorp/2005/02/how_we_work_bil.html |title=How we work: Bill Murray, actor |publisher=rodcorp |accessdate=January 11, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080107192513/http://rodcorp.typepad.com/rodcorp/2005/02/how_we_work_bil.html |archivedate=January 7, 2008 |deadurl=no }} This practice has the downside of sometimes preventing him from taking parts in films such as ''[[Who Framed Roger Rabbit]]'', ''[[Monsters, Inc.]]'', ''[[The Squid and the Whale]]'', ''[[Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (film)|Charlie and the Chocolate Factory]]'', and ''[[Little Miss Sunshine]]''.{{cite web|last=Heritage|first=Stuart|title=Bill Murray is 60! Celebrate with 60 Bill Murray facts|date=September 10, 2010|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/sep/11/bill-murray-60th-birthday-facts|accessdate=May 12, 2015}}{{cite web|last=Evans|first=Bradford|title=The Lost Roles of Bill Murray|date=February 17, 2011|url=http://splitsider.com/2011/02/the-lost-roles-of-bill-murray/|accessdate=May 25, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150520115025/http://splitsider.com/2011/02/the-lost-roles-of-bill-murray|archive-date=May 20, 2015|dead-url=yes}}{{cite web |last=Farr |first=John |title=Bill Murray and the Roles That Got Away |date=November 11, 2014 |origyear=September 19, 2014 |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/john-farr/bill-murray-and-the-roles_b_5850434.html |accessdate=May 25, 2015}}{{cite web |last=Locke |first=Greg W. |title=The Top 25 Roles Bill Murray Didn’t Take |date=August 26, 2011 |url=http://www.zecatalist.com/lists/the-top-25-roles-bob-murray-didnt-take/ |accessdate=May 25, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150619014025/http://www.zecatalist.com/lists/the-top-25-roles-bob-murray-didnt-take/ | archivedate=June 19, 2015}} When asked about this practice, however, Murray seemed content with his inaccessibility, stating, "It's not that hard. If you have a good script that's what gets you involved. People say they can't find me. Well, if you can write a good script, that's a lot harder than finding someone. I don't worry about it; it's not my problem."[http://the-talks.com/interviews/bill-murray/ Bill Murray Interview]; The Talks{{clear left}} Murray's popularity has been such that ({{as of|2017|lc=y}}) he holds an iconic status in U.S. popular culture. Murray's eccentric and irreverent style of comedy, both on-screen and in his personal life, has caused him to be seen as a folk hero to many making him a significant meme in various media including books and the internet.{{cite news | author=Kurutz, Steven | title=The Peculiar Ascent of Bill Murray to Secular Saint | date=November 30, 2015| publisher=New York Times | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/04/fashion/mens-style/the-peculiar-ascent-of-bill-murray-to-secular-saint.html}}{{cite web |author= Burnett III, Zaron | title=Why the Internet is obsessed with Bill Murray |date= October 13, 2014 |publisher= The Daily Dot |url= https://www.dailydot.com/via/bill-murray-holy-fool-internet/}} In 2016 he was awarded the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor by the [[Kennedy Center]]. ==Personal life== [[File:CrossroadsGuitarFestival2007.jpg|thumb|[[Eric Clapton]] and Murray kicking off the Crossroads Guitar Festival in 2007]] During the filming of ''Stripes'', Murray married Margaret Kelly on [[Super Bowl]] Sunday in Las Vegas on January 25, 1981. Later, they remarried in Chicago for their families. Margaret gave birth to two sons, Homer (born 1982) and Luke (born 1985). Luke is an assistant basketball coach at the [[Louisville Cardinals men's basketball|University of Louisville]], moving from his former position as an assistant at [[Xavier Musketeers men's basketball|Xavier University]] in 2018 shortly after former Xavier head coach [[Chris Mack (basketball)|Chris Mack]] was hired to the same position at Louisville.{{cite web|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2015/05/luke-murray-xavier|title=New Xavier assistant Luke Murray’s biggest recruiting advantage? His dad was in Space Jam – For The Win|author=|date=|work=For The Win|accessdate=October 4, 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.courier-journal.com/story/sports/college/louisville/2018/04/07/louisville-basketball-coaches-staff-chris-mack-dino-gaudio-luke-murray-mike-pegues/495978002/ |title=University of Louisville announces full men's basketball coaching staff |first=Jake |last=Lourim |newspaper=[[The Courier-Journal|Courier Journal]] |location=[[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville, KY]] |date=April 7, 2018 |accessdate=April 9, 2018}} Following Murray's affair with Jennifer Butler, the couple divorced in 1996.{{cite web|last=Martin|first=Annie|title=Bill Murray says he is single but not lonely|date=October 10, 2014|publisher=[[United Press International]]|url=http://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/2014/10/10/Bill-Murray-says-he-is-single-but-not-lonely/2591412954407/|accessdate=January 5, 2017}} In 1997, he married Butler. Together, they have four sons: Caleb (born January 11, 1993), Jackson (born October 6, 1995), Cooper (born January 27, 1997), and Lincoln (born May 30, 2001). Butler filed for divorce on May 12, 2008, accusing Murray of [[domestic violence]], infidelity, and addictions to [[Sexual addiction|sex]], [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]], and [[Alcoholism|alcohol]].{{cite web |url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2008/may/29/bill_murray_sued_divorce42566/ |work=The Post and Courier |title=Bill Murray sued for divorce |location=Charleston, South Carolina |publisher=Charleston.net |date=May 29, 2008 |accessdate=March 9, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100324181037/http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2008/may/29/bill_murray_sued_divorce42566/ |archivedate=March 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes }} Their divorce was finalized on June 13, 2008.{{cite web|title=Bill Murray's divorce is finalized|date=June 26, 2008|publisher=''[[USA Today]]''|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2008-06-26-murraydivorce_N.htm|accessdate=October 8, 2015}} Murray stated in a 1984 interview: "I'm definitely a religious person, but it doesn't have much to do with [[Catholic Church|Catholicism]] anymore. I don't think about Catholicism as much."{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LTfqBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT306&lpg=PT306&dq=bill+murray+no+longer+identifies+catholic&source=bl&ots=ea89K5CUnY&sig=HQRxiZYJnI0nWUqh6CV0BmTwNYg&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=bill%20murray%20no%20longer%20identifies%20catholic&f=false|last=Schnakenberg|first=Robert|title=The Big Bad Book of Bill Murray: A Critical Appreciation of the World's Finest Actor|year=2015|publisher=Quirk Books|isbn=9781594748226}} Murray was once pulled over by Swedish police on suspicion of [[Drunk drivers|driving a golf cart under the influence of alcohol]]. Murray has homes in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[Rancho Santa Fe, California]],https://yournorthcounty.com/celebrities-that-live-in-san-diego-north-county/ [[Martha's Vineyard]], [[Massachusetts]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mvmagazine.com/2006/july/hot_tin_roof.php |title=Under (one) Hot Tin Roof |publisher=Martha's Vineyard Magazine |accessdate=January 11, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070513075025/http://www.mvmagazine.com/2006/july/hot_tin_roof.php |archivedate=May 13, 2007 }} [[Charleston, South Carolina]], and [[Palisades, New York]], a suburb of [[New York City]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mondostars.com/entertainment/billmurray.html |title=Bill Murray: Funny, crazy and sweet |publisher=MondoStars |accessdate=January 11, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071105044447/http://www.mondostars.com/entertainment/billmurray.html |archivedate=November 5, 2007 }} Between 2008 and 2013, Murray maintained a residence in the [[Greenwich Village]] neighborhood of [[Lower Manhattan]].{{cite web |url=http://therealdeal.com/blog/2013/05/23/bill-murray-lowers-asking-price-at-the-villager/|title=Rent for Bill Murray's former Village pad drops by $2K|publisher =The Real Deal|accessdate=May 24, 2013}} During the [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000 presidential campaign]], Murray supported [[Green Party (United States)|Green Party]] candidate [[Ralph Nader]].{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D00E4DD113FF936A25753C1A9669C8B63|title= THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE GREEN PARTY; In Nader Supporters' Math, Gore Equals Bush|publisher =The New York Times|accessdate=January 11, 2008 | first=David W. | last=Chen | date=October 15, 2000}} He also donated $1,000 to former Governor of Nebraska [[Bob Kerrey]]'s successful election to the United States Senate in [[United States Senate election in Nebraska, 1988|1988]].{{cite web|url=http://www.newsmeat.com/celebrity_political_donations/Bill_Murray.php |title=Bill Murray's Federal Campaign Contribution Report |publisher=Newsmeat.com |date= |accessdate=July 29, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120922231524/http://newsmeat.com/celebrity_political_donations/Bill_Murray.php |archivedate=September 22, 2012 }} [[File:Bill Murray Fighting Illini 2005.jpg|thumb|Bill Murray cheering for the [[Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball]] team at the [[2005 Final Four]] in [[St. Louis]]]] Murray is a fan of several [[sports in Chicago|Chicago professional sports teams]], especially the [[Chicago Cubs]], [[Chicago Bears]], and the [[Chicago Bulls]].{{cite web |title=9 Things We Love About Bill Murray |work=back9network.com |url=http://www.back9network.com/article/9-things-we-love-about-bill-murray/ |accessdate=September 21, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140925094359/http://www.back9network.com/article/9-things-we-love-about-bill-murray/ |archivedate=September 25, 2014 }} (He was once a guest [[color commentator]] for a Cubs game during the 1980s.){{cite news|last=Wine |first=Steven |title=Comedian Bill Murray lightens Cubs' mood – at least briefly |work= |publisher=Yahoo! Sports |date=September 27, 2007 |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/mlb/news;_ylt=Ak6ARa.k7P1_XBcslCIr3LMV0bYF?slug=ap-cubs-murray&prov=ap&type=lgns |accessdate=September 28, 2007 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} He was in attendance, along with fellow Cubs fans [[John Cusack]], [[Eddie Vedder]] and [[Bonnie Hunt]], during the Cubs' historic Game Seven victory during the [[2016 World Series]]. Murray is an avid [[Quinnipiac University]] basketball fan, where his son served as head of basketball operations, and he is a regular fixture at home games. He cheered courtside for the [[2004–05 Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball team|Illinois Fighting Illini]]'s game against the 2004–05 [[Arizona Wildcats]] in the Regional Final game in Chicago. He is a fixture at home games of those teams when in his native Chicago. After traveling to Florida during the Cubs' playoff run to help "inspire" the team (Murray joked with Cubs slugger [[Aramis Ramírez]] he was very ill and needed two home runs to give him the hope to live),{{cite news |last=Keller |first=Tom |title=Murray visits with Cubs prior to finale |publisher=MLB.com |date=September 27, 2007 |url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article_entertainment.jsp?ymd=20070927&content_id=2234194&vkey=entertainment&fext=.jsp |accessdate=November 12, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012173906/http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article_entertainment.jsp?ymd=20070927&content_id=2234194&vkey=entertainment&fext=.jsp |archivedate=October 12, 2007 |deadurl=no }} he was invited to the champagne party in the Cubs' clubhouse when the team clinched the NL Central in late September 2007, along with fellow actors [[John Cusack]], [[Bernie Mac]], [[James Belushi]], and former Cubs player [[Ron Santo]]. Murray appears in Santo's documentary, ''[[This Old Cub]]''. In 2006, Murray became the sixth recipient of [[Baseball Reliquary]]'s annual Hilda Award,[http://www.baseballreliquary.org/awards/hilda-award-recipients/#2006-bill-murray "Hilda Award recipients"]. Baseball Reliquary. Retrieved August 29, 2015. established in 2001 "to recognize distinguished service to the game by a fan."[http://www.baseballreliquary.org/awards/hilda-award-recipients/ "Baseball Reliquary – Hilda Award"]. Baseball Reliquary. Retrieved August 29, 2015. He sang "[[Take Me Out to the Ballgame]]" during a [[2016 World Series]] game at [[Wrigley Field]].{{cite news|last1=McCluskey|first1=Megan|title=Bill Murray Is Singing ‘Take Me Out to the Ballgame’ at the World Series|url=http://time.com/4549552/bill-murray-cubs-world-series-take-me-out-to-the-ballgame/|accessdate=November 18, 2016|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}} [[File:2013 Golden Globe Awards (8378777269).jpg|thumb|190px|Murray at the [[70th Golden Globe Awards]], January 13, 2013]] As a Chicago native, Murray appeared at the 50th annual [[Chicago Air & Water Show]] in August 2008. He performed a [[tandem jump]] with the [[U.S. Army Parachute Team]] Golden Knights.{{cite news | url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2008-07-22/news/0807210434_1_brady-bunch-jump-chicago-air | title=Bill Murray to parachute at Chicago Air & Water Show | date=July 21, 2008 | accessdate=July 21, 2008 | work=Chicago Tribune}} He was the emcee for [[Eric Clapton]]'s [[Crossroads Guitar Festival]] on July 28, 2007, where he dressed in various guises of Clapton as he appeared through the years. He was MC again in 2010. In 1987, he made a sizable donation to assist in the development and building of the Nathalie Salmon House. This home has been able to provide [[affordable housing]] for low-income seniors. Michael and Lilo Salmon, the founders of Housing Opportunities and Maintenance for the Elderly (HOME), have credited Murray with performing "miracles" for them. ===On-set feuds=== Murray has been known for his mood swings, leading [[Dan Aykroyd]] to refer to him as "The Murricane".{{cite web|last=Labrecque|first=Jeff|title=Bill Murray: Curious case of Hollywood's white whale|date=August 27, 2013|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|url=http://ew.com/article/2013/08/27/bill-murray-curious-case-hollywoods-white-whale/|accessdate=March 20, 2018}} Murray has said of his reputation: "I remember a friend said to me a while back: 'You have a reputation.' And I said: 'What?' And he said: 'Yeah, you have a reputation of being difficult to work with.' But I only got that reputation from people I didn't like working with, or people who didn't know how to work, or what work is. [[Jim Jarmusch|Jim]], [[Wes Anderson|Wes]] and [[Sofia Coppola|Sofia]], they know what it is to work, and they understand how you're supposed to treat people."{{cite web|author=[[Associated Press]]|title=Bill Murray thinks his reputation is unfair|date=June 1, 2018|publisher=''[[Globe Gazette]]''|url=https://globegazette.com/entertainment/movies/bill-murray-thinks-his-reputation-is-unfair/article_97559f67-fe28-5a44-a9ba-cfc71ccce92e.html|accessdate=June 29, 2018}}{{cite web|author=[[Associated Press]]|title=Bill Murray thinks his reputation is unfair|date=June 1, 2018|publisher=''[[Sioux City Journal]]''|url=https://siouxcityjournal.com/entertainment/movies/bill-murray-thinks-his-reputation-is-unfair/article_e5fe3c73-46f2-5f5e-a694-d0edff5bc214.html|accessdate=July 1, 2018}} In the book ''Live from New York: An Uncensored History of Saturday Night Live, as Told By Its Stars, Writers and Guests'', [[Chevy Chase]] recalls being confronted by Murray shortly before an ''SNL'' broadcast in which Chase had returned to guest host. The issue, likely to do with Chase's insistence on doing the "Weekend Update" segment that had been taken over by [[Jane Curtin]], led to Murray and Chase trading insults, with Murray telling Chase to go have sex with Jacqueline Carlin, Chase's wife at the time, while Chase commented that Murray's face looked "like something [[Neil Armstrong]] had landed on”. The argument eventually turned physical.{{cite web|last=Read |first=Max |title=He's Not Chevy, He's an Asshole: A History of Chevy Chase's Horrific Behavior |date=April 5, 2012 |publisher=''[[Gawker]]'' |url=http://gawker.com/5899097/hes-not-chevy-hes-an-asshole-a-history-of-chevy-chases-horrific-behavior |accessdate=May 30, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526085644/http://gawker.com/5899097/hes-not-chevy-hes-an-asshole-a-history-of-chevy-chases-horrific-behavior |archivedate=May 26, 2015 |df=mdy }} Murray later said of the incident, "It was an Oedipal thing, a rupture. Because we all felt mad he had left us, and somehow I was the anointed avenging angel, who had to speak for everyone. But Chevy and I are friends now. It’s all fine."{{cite web|last=de Semlyen|first=Nick|title=Bill Murray On Fighting Chevy Chase|date=May 18, 2012|publisher=''Empire''|url=http://www.empireonline.com/News/story.asp?nid=34011|accessdate=May 30, 2015}} The two later starred together in ''[[Caddyshack]]'' in 1980. According to [[Den of Geek]], Murray did not get along with [[Sean Young]] during the production of ''[[Stripes (film)|Stripes]]'' and has refused to work with her ever again.{{cite web|last=Brew|first=Simon|title=14 Co-stars Who Really Didn't Get Along|date=September 27, 2013|publisher=[[Den of Geek]]|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/us/movies/co-stars/198892/14-co-stars-who-really-didnt-get-along|accessdate=May 29, 2016}} Murray has said in interviews that he did not get along with film director [[Richard Donner]] while filming ''[[Scrooged]]'', stating that they would disagree with each other.{{cite web|last=Ebert|first=Roger|title=BILL MURRAY, "QUICK CHANGE" ARTIST|date=July 13, 1990|publisher=''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/interviews/bill-murray-quick-change-artist|accessdate=July 12, 2015}}{{cite web|last=Mullins|first=Jenna|title=NEWS/ 56 Facts You May Not Know About Your Favorite Holiday Films|date=December 18, 2014|publisher=''[[E! News]]''|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/607359/56-facts-you-may-not-know-about-your-favorite-holiday-films|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} Donner said of Murray: "He's superbly creative but occasionally difficult – as difficult as any actor."{{cite web|last=Puskar|first=Susan|title=Bill Murray is a creep in the role of 'Scrooge'|date=December 18, 1988|publisher=''[[The Blade (Toledo)|The Blade]]''|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19881218&id=2FBPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9wIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6934,519903&hl=en|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} Both Murray and [[Richard Dreyfuss]] have confirmed in separate interviews that they did not get along with each other during the making of ''[[What About Bob?]]''.{{cite web|last=Meyers|first=Kate|title=A Bill Murray filmography|date=March 19, 1993|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|url=http://www.ew.com/article/1993/03/19/bill-murray-filmography|accessdate=May 28, 2015}}{{cite web|last=Rabin|first=Nathan|title=Richard Dreyfuss|date=October 8, 2009|publisher=''[[The A.V. Club]]''|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/richard-dreyfuss-33769|accessdate=May 28, 2015}} In addition, the film's producer [[Laura Ziskin]] recalled having a disagreement with Murray that led him to toss her into a lake.{{cite web|last=Brownfield|first=Paul|title=What about Bill? (Page 2 of 4)|date=February 29, 2004|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/feb/29/entertainment/ca-brownfield29/2|accessdate=January 4, 2017}}{{cite web|last2=Goldstein|first2=Patrick|last1=Horn|first1=John|title=Even on loose sets, barbarian behavior rare|date=October 5, 2003|publisher=''[[Chicago Tribune]]''|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2003-10-05/news/0310050474_1_numerous-major-movie-credits-sets-are-self-contained-societies-correct-adult-behavior|accessdate=January 4, 2017}} Ziskin confirmed in 2003, "Bill also threatened to throw me across the parking lot and then broke my sunglasses and threw them across the parking lot. I was furious and outraged at the time, but having produced a dozen movies, I can safely say it is not common behavior."{{cite web|last2=Goldstein|first2=Patrick|last1=Horn|first1=John|title=Even on loose sets, barbarian behavior rare (Page 2 of 2)|date=October 5, 2003|publisher=''[[Chicago Tribune]]''|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2003-10-05/news/0310050474_1_numerous-major-movie-credits-sets-are-self-contained-societies-correct-adult-behavior/2|accessdate=January 4, 2017}} Murray also had a falling out with film director and longtime collaborator [[Harold Ramis]] during the production of ''[[Groundhog Day (film)|Groundhog Day]]''. According to screenwriter [[Danny Rubin]], "They were like two brothers who weren’t getting along." As a result, ''Groundhog Day'' ultimately served as the final film collaboration between Murray and Ramis. Murray eventually reconciled with Ramis just before Ramis's death in February 2014.{{cite web|last=Wakeman|first=Gregory|title=How Groundhog Day Ruined Bill Murray And Harold Ramis’ Partnership|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/How-Groundhog-Day-Ruined-Bill-Murray-Harold-Ramis-Partnership-67345.html|accessdate=May 28, 2015}}{{cite web | last=Friend | first=Tad | url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2004/04/19/040419fa_fact3?currentPage=7 | title=Annals of Hollywood: Comedy First | publisher=The New Yorker | date=January 7, 2009 | accessdate=May 28, 2015}}{{cite web | last=Heisler | first=Steve | url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/harold-ramis,29410/ | title=Harold Ramis | Film | publisher=A.V. Club | date= | accessdate=May 28, 2015}}{{cite web|last=Lang|first=Brent|title=Harold Ramis and Bill Murray: Inside The ‘Groundhog Day’ Duo’s Decade-Long Feud|date=February 25, 2014|publisher=[[TheWrap]]|url=http://www.thewrap.com/harold-ramis-bill-murray-inside-groundhog-day-duos-decade-long-feud/|accessdate=May 28, 2015}} During the making of ''[[Charlie's Angels (2000 film)|Charlie's Angels]]'', [[Lucy Liu]] allegedly threw punches at Murray after he told her that she could not act.{{cite web|title=Famous co-stars who absolutely hated each other|date=November 4, 2014|publisher=[[News.com.au]]|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/movies/famous-costars-who-absolutely-hated-each-other/story-e6frfmvr-1227112569514|accessdate=May 28, 2015}} However, Murray claims that he and Liu only had an argument rather than a feud and that they have "made peace" since then.{{cite web|last=Williams|first=Steven|title=Bill Murray Explains That His Feud With Lucy Liu Never Even Occurred|date=September 11, 2003|publisher=[[Contactmusic.com]]|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/bill-murray/news/bill-clears-up-charlie.s-angels-feud-with-lucy|accessdate=May 28, 2015}} Murray has also denied a claim that he head-butted [[McG]], the director of the film.{{cite web|last=Nashawaty|first=Chris|title=Bill Murray says 'Charlie's Angels' director 'deserves to die'|date=October 20, 2009|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2009/10/20/bill-murray-says-charlies-angels-director-deserves-to-die|accessdate=May 28, 2015}} ''[[Lost in Translation (film)|Lost in Translation]]'' director [[Sofia Coppola]] said that the central scene of [[Scarlett Johansson]] and Murray lying on the bed together took multiple takes because the actors did not seem to be getting along. She eventually stopped for the day and started again the next morning.{{cite web|last=Stern|first=Marlow|title=Sofia Coppola Discusses ‘Lost in Translation’ on Its 10th Anniversary|date=September 12, 2013|publisher=''[[The Daily Beast]]''|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/sofia-coppola-discusses-lost-in-translation-on-its-10th-anniversary|accessdate=June 29, 2018}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Nominated—[[MTV Movie Award for Best Comedic Performance]] |- | ''[[Mad Dog and Glory]]'' | Frank Milo | |- | 1994 | ''[[Ed Wood (film)|Ed Wood]]'' | [[Bunny Breckinridge]] | |- | rowspan="3" | 1996 | ''[[Kingpin (1996 film)|Kingpin]]'' | Ernie McCracken | |- | ''[[Larger than Life (film)|Larger than Life]]'' | Jack Corcoran | |- | ''[[Space Jam]]'' | Himself | |- | 1997 | ''[[The Man Who Knew Too Little]]'' | Wallace Ritchie | |- | rowspan="3" | 1998 | ''[[Wild Things (film)|Wild Things]]'' | Kenneth Bowden | [[Los Angeles Film Critics Association Award for Best Supporting Actor]] |- | ''[[With Friends Like These...]]'' | Maurice Melnick | |- | ''[[Rushmore (film)|Rushmore]]'' | Herman Blume | [[American Comedy Awards|American Comedy Award for Funniest Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture]]
